I don't want to create a toxic review, but I'd like to share some of my experiences. I have a sim rig for racing mainly, and I play ETS2 for 'spare/relax' time.

I can see the overwhelming positivity towards the game and a strong community, but some basic issues still exist after so many years of development, and I find it strange.

The hitbox of objects and even cars sometimes is bizarre. Hopefully, no explanation required.

I got to a mission that was impossible to park because objects around were hugging my truck and bouncing it, damaging it every second. My wheel with force feedback went crazy, almost hurting me. I ended up with the truck stuck, getting hits like in an arcade fight game with a massive service bill at the end.

The accident simulation is close to horrible. When you hit a car or a corner of a wall or building, it's just like a rock hitting a rock with some additional weird behaviour of pull and push.

AI is quite buggy. Today, I was driving on a highway, and there was an incident 'placed' on the way. AI cars were flying through it completely ignoring it, then suddenly one hit all the cars on the way (I don't know why suddenly that AI car couldn't go through). Everything was flying on my screen and hitting my truck weirdly, more damage.

Shouldn't this game be investing in the physics, especially the objects, when it comes to the challenges of driving and parking?

Boring.
No fun.

23 more hours into the game. I was so wrong. This game is great. If you want to punish yourself. 
Friends keep telling me "it will get better". Well, I'll get back to you when that happens. Right now it's a NFS with trucks, which move like trucks. The level of realism is impressive.

- Any time you dare to interact with any polygon in this game (at any speed) it's a gamble of whether the physics engine decides to do absolutely nothing, or catapult your truck 20m into the air and make it do 7.3 somersaults. This gets about 10x worse at higher speeds and 100x worse on multiplayer.
- NPCs will always run into you in specific scenarios (which you have to pay for), regardless of hazard lights or you spamming the hell out of the horn key.
- Achievements range from super easy all the way to "spend 50 hours waiting for RNG to give you this very specific cargo from this very specific city, which you have to drive to this other very specific city. Three times by the way. Also we won't tell you which companies count towards this achievement, tee hee :3"
- "Features" like the lane keeping assistant are over-sensitive and imbalanced and will make your truck turn 90Â° on a whim randomly (probably because road segments are inconsistently made).
- There are roads hidden from your GPS until you find them which have no "X overlay", so the game tries to make this the indicator that you found a hidden road. However, 98% of roads that don't have the X overlay instead just have a plain invisible wall which you'll run into, effectively disabling the entire hidden roads mechanic.
- In fullscreen mode, my Firefox PiP player consistently freezes. This doesn't happen with any other game or on windowed mode.
- Graphics are decent, environments are very beautiful, realistic and stay engaging (except the Iberia DLC). But if you can't manage to have decently realistic gameplay and physics, it doesn't amount to anything.

Awesome, top-notch game that is not only a gold-standard for trucking simulators but also for quality gaming software in general.

Unfortunately learning that SCS is currently developing a "Heart of Russia" DLC has entirely soured me from playing this game in the future.  I hate to mix politics with leisure, but have to make an exception in this case.  The optics of releasing a such a product during Russia's ongoing attempted genocide of the Ukrainian people and bloody conquest of sovereign Ukrainian soil could not be worse.

Such a DLC can easily be (mis)interpreted(?) as promoting Russian imperialism with a blind-eye towards the unjust barbaric massacre of Ukrainians and attempted conquest of their nation.  Especially when its release  has apparently been prioritized over a Ukraine DLC (any takers for a research trip there).   

What exactly is the long-term road-map here?  Glorify the "victorious" past of Russia's interior, while ignoring any current and future humanitarian atrocities it commits at its borders?  Then wait to see where those borders settle out before making a DLC of Ukraine, assuming it still exists as nation, or release a "Russia Westward Expansion" DLC otherwise?

I also contend that my comments are entirely appropriate for a video game review.  All product reviews are subjective to the reviewer's personal experience.  In this case, seeing that a game will eventually include content that egregiously offends my personal sensibilities has now completely negated any enjoyment I can get from it.  

How can I recommend a game that I no longer enjoy playing as a direct result of future content announced by it's creator?  I cannot, and thus the downward thumb.
